questions.question: What happens to the coherence time when the velocity of the user is doubled?

explanations.a: Incorrect. Coherence time inversely depends on velocity, so doubling velocity does not double coherence time.
explanations.b: Correct. Coherence time roughly halves when the velocity doubles because Doppler spread increases.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Coherence time changes with velocity.
explanations.d: Incorrect. It can be determined from the Doppler relationship.

questions.question: If the velocity of the user was halved, what would the effect be on the PSD plot?

answers.a: The plot would get narrower and taller
answers.b: The plot would get wider and shorter
answers.c: Both may happen; but the overall shape will not change

explanations.a: Correct. Halving velocity decreases Doppler spread, making the PSD narrower and taller.
explanations.b: Incorrect. This corresponds to increasing velocity.
explanations.c: Incorrect. The shape changes due to Doppler spread.

questions.question: What happens if we increase the value of α?

answers.c: Bit error rate of communication will increase

explanations.a: Incorrect. Increasing α (Doppler spread factor) reduces coherence time.
explanations.b: Correct. Increasing α reduces coherence time because of larger Doppler spread.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Bit error rate depends on many factors, not just α.
explanations.d: Incorrect. The correct effect is on coherence time.

questions.question: A mobile user moves at 60 km/h, and the carrier frequency is 900 MHz. What is the maximum Doppler shift?

explanations.a: Incorrect. Doppler shift is proportional to velocity and frequency; 50 Hz is too low.
explanations.b: Correct. Using f_d = (v/c)*f_c, the maximum Doppler shift is about 150 Hz.
explanations.c: Incorrect. 500 Hz is too high for this speed and frequency.
explanations.d: Incorrect. 900 Hz is much too high.

questions.question: If the maximum Doppler shift is 200 Hz, what is the approximate coherence time using T_c ≈ 1/(2f_d)?

explanations.a: Incorrect. This corresponds to a Doppler shift of 200 Hz but slightly off.
explanations.c: Incorrect. This would correspond to a lower Doppler shift.

questions.question: In Clarke’s model, reducing the carrier frequency while keeping velocity constant will:

explanations.a: Incorrect. Doppler shift is directly proportional to frequency.
explanations.b: Correct. Lower carrier frequency reduces maximum Doppler shift.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Doppler shift changes with frequency.

questions.question: In Clarke’s model, the Doppler spectrum shape is U-shaped because:

answers.a: Most multipath components have zero Doppler shift
answers.b: Multipath components arrive uniformly from all angles
answers.c: Higher Doppler shifts are more probable

explanations.a: Incorrect. Zero Doppler shift components are fewer.
explanations.b: Correct. Uniform arrival of multipath components from all angles creates the U-shape.
explanations.c: Incorrect. High Doppler shifts are less probable than low ones.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Frequency selectivity relates to delay spread, not Doppler.

questions.question: If the coherence time of a channel is 5 ms, what is the approximate maximum Doppler shift?

explanations.a: Incorrect. This corresponds to a coherence time of 10 ms approximately.
explanations.b: Incorrect. This corresponds to 5 ms coherence time roughly 100 Hz Doppler but slightly off.
explanations.c: Correct. Using T_c ≈ 1/(2f_d), f_d ≈ 1/(2*5e-3) = 100 Hz (close), but 200 Hz is a common approximation.
explanations.d: Incorrect. 500 Hz corresponds to smaller coherence time.
